body_html:
For clarification, is the problem that the documentation lists different argument names than what is actually accepted?

Yes

For this case, the docs suggests torch.matmul(tensor1, tensor2, out=None) which is not entirely a problem because "tensor1, tensor2" are supposed to be positional arguments. I do agree that it would be nice for it to match what the args actually are.

There are two fixes for this.

  1. Modify Declarations.cwrap, derivatives.yaml to match docs
  2. Modify docs.

I am inclined towards 1, in interest of backward compatibility.

body:
> For clarification, is the problem that the documentation lists different argument names than what is actually accepted?

Yes

> For this case, the docs suggests torch.matmul(tensor1, tensor2, out=None) which is not entirely a problem because "tensor1, tensor2" are supposed to be positional arguments. I do agree that it would be nice for it to match what the args actually are.

There are two fixes for this.
1. Modify Declarations.cwrap, derivatives.yaml to match docs
2. Modify docs.

I am inclined towards 1, in interest of backward compatibility.
